title: How to Make "No Knead" Whole Wheat Bread

steps.headline: Use a measuring cup and proof the yeast in 1/2 cup of warm water (100 degrees F) and the honey.
steps.description: This takes about 15 minutes until it foams up.

steps.headline: While proofing the yeast mix all dry ingredients in a large bowl, it should hold at least 5.5 quarts.
steps.description: Ceramic or stainless steel preferred. After the yeast has proofed and is activated, add it to the flour and mix with a wood spoon and bring the total water added, including yeast water, to 3 1/8 cups. The dough should be a bit ragged. If it's "batter-like" or gummy, add more flour. All the dry mix should be incorporated into the dough.

steps.headline: Using a few drops of oil, roast the seed and nut mixture (not the flax meal though) until lightly browned, set aside to cool.
Leave the dough in the mixing bowl, cover it with plastic wrap and set on a counter.
steps.description: The warmer the spot, the faster the rise.

steps.headline: Let the bread dough rise at least 8 hours, overnight is fine.
steps.description: It will double in size but if it sags, or you let it rise 24 hours or more, that's fine, as it will taste more sourdough-like.

steps.headline: Turn the dough out of the bowl onto a floured surface and, with floured hands, fold it over itself 5 to 10 times, shaping it as desired.
Cover the dough with a clean cloth and let it rise two more hours.
steps.description: Before the two hours are up, preheat the oven to 450F.

steps.headline: Very lightly oil or grease a dutch oven's sides and sprinkle a tablespoon of cornmeal into the bottom.
Ideally, use a cast iron or porcelain iron dutch oven.
steps.description: You can also use a metal roasting pan or bread pan but you must be able to tightly cover it with a lid or aluminum foil.

steps.headline: Once the stove is hot and two hours are up, carefully scoop the dough into the dutch oven, don't smooth it out, cover it, and put it into the stove's oven for 40 minutes.
After 40 minutes, uncover the bread and bake it for 20 more minutes until it's crusty and golden brown.
steps.description: Turn the bread out onto a cooling rack, it should sound hollow when thumped.

text: Use a measuring cup and proof the yeast in 1/2 cup of warm water (100 degrees F) and the honey. This takes about 15 minutes until it foams up. While proofing the yeast mix all dry ingredients in a large bowl, it should hold at least 5.5 quarts. Ceramic or stainless steel preferred. After the yeast has proofed and is activated, add it to the flour and mix with a wood spoon and bring the total water added, including yeast water, to 3 1/8 cups. The dough should be a bit ragged. If it's "batter-like" or gummy, add more flour. All the dry mix should be incorporated into the dough. Using a few drops of oil, roast the seed and nut mixture (not the flax meal though) until lightly browned, set aside to cool.  Leave the dough in the mixing bowl, cover it with plastic wrap and set on a counter. The warmer the spot, the faster the rise. Let the bread dough rise at least 8 hours, overnight is fine. It will double in size but if it sags, or you let it rise 24 hours or more, that's fine, as it will taste more sourdough-like. Turn the dough out of the bowl onto a floured surface and, with floured hands, fold it over itself 5 to 10 times, shaping it as desired.  Cover the dough with a clean cloth and let it rise two more hours. Before the two hours are up, preheat the oven to 450F. Very lightly oil or grease a dutch oven's sides and sprinkle a tablespoon of cornmeal into the bottom.  Ideally, use a cast iron or porcelain iron dutch oven. You can also use a metal roasting pan or bread pan but you must be able to tightly cover it with a lid or aluminum foil. Once the stove is hot and two hours are up, carefully scoop the dough into the dutch oven, don't smooth it out, cover it, and put it into the stove's oven for 40 minutes.  After 40 minutes, uncover the bread and bake it for 20 more minutes until it's crusty and golden brown. Turn the bread out onto a cooling rack, it should sound hollow when thumped.
tyn_model: cast iron or porcelain iron dutch oven
